caret-position.name: CaretPosition
caret-position.summary: The CaretPosition interface represents the caret position, an indicator for the text insertion point. You can get a CaretPosition using the Document.caretPositionFromPoint() method.
caret-position.title: CaretPosition

dom-document-caretpositionfrompoint.name: caretPositionFromPoint
dom-document-caretpositionfrompoint.summary: The caretPositionFromPoint() method of the Document interface returns a CaretPosition object, containing the DOM node, along with the caret and caret's character offset within that node.
dom-document-caretpositionfrompoint.title: Document: caretPositionFromPoint() method

dom-document-elementfrompoint.name: elementFromPoint
dom-document-elementfrompoint.summary: The elementFromPoint() method, available on the Document object, returns the topmost Element at the specified coordinates (relative to the viewport).

chrome.notes: Before Chrome 66, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

opera.notes: Before Opera 53, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

opera_android.notes: Before Opera Android 47, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

webview_android.notes: Before WebView 66, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

edge_blink.notes: Before Chrome 66, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

dom-document-elementfrompoint.title: Document: elementFromPoint() method

dom-document-elementsfrompoint.name: elementsFromPoint
dom-document-elementsfrompoint.summary: The elementsFromPoint() method of the Document interface returns an array of all elements at the specified coordinates (relative to the viewport). The elements are ordered from the topmost to the bottommost box of the viewport.

chrome.notes: Before Chrome 66, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

ie.notes: Returns a NodeList instead of an array. See the MSDN documentation. Returns null when the point provided has no elements beneath it (e.g., when given a point outside the document).

edge_blink.notes: Before Chrome 66, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

dom-document-elementsfrompoint.title: Document: elementsFromPoint() method

eventdef-document-scroll.name: scroll_event
eventdef-document-scroll.summary: The scroll event fires when the document view has been scrolled. To detect when scrolling has completed, see the Document: scrollend event. For element scrolling, see Element: scroll event.
eventdef-document-scroll.title: Document: scroll event

eventdef-document-scroll.name: scroll_event
eventdef-document-scroll.summary: The scroll event fires when an element has been scrolled. To detect when scrolling has completed, see the Element: scrollend event.
eventdef-document-scroll.title: Element: scroll event

eventdef-document-scroll.name: scroll_event
eventdef-document-scroll.summary: The scroll event of the VisualViewport interface is fired when the visual viewport is scrolled.

chrome.notes: The onscroll event handler property is not supported.

edge_blink.notes: The onscroll event handler property is not supported.

eventdef-document-scroll.title: VisualViewport: scroll event

eventdef-document-scrollend.name: scrollend_event
eventdef-document-scrollend.summary: The scrollend event fires when the document view has completed scrolling. Scrolling is considered completed when the scroll position has no more pending updates and the user has completed their gesture.
eventdef-document-scrollend.title: Document: scrollend event

eventdef-document-scrollend.name: scrollend_event
eventdef-document-scrollend.summary: The scrollend event fires when element scrolling has completed. Scrolling is considered completed when the scroll position has no more pending updates and the user has completed their gesture.
eventdef-document-scrollend.title: Element: scrollend event

dom-document-scrollingelement.name: scrollingElement
dom-document-scrollingelement.summary: The scrollingElement read-only property of the Document interface returns a reference to the Element that scrolls the document. In standards mode, this is the root element of the document, document.documentElement.
dom-document-scrollingelement.title: Document: scrollingElement property

extensions-to-the-document-interface.name: Document
extensions-to-the-document-interface.summary: The Document interface represents any web page loaded in the browser and serves as an entry point into the web page's content, which is the DOM tree.
extensions-to-the-document-interface.title: Document

dom-element-clientheight.name: clientHeight
dom-element-clientheight.summary: The Element.clientHeight read-only property is zero for elements with no CSS or inline layout boxes; otherwise, it's the inner height of an element in pixels. It includes padding but excludes borders, margins, and horizontal scrollbars (if present).
dom-element-clientheight.title: Element: clientHeight property

dom-element-clientleft.name: clientLeft
dom-element-clientleft.summary: The width of the left border of an element in pixels. It includes the width of the vertical scrollbar if the text direction of the element is right-to-left and if there is an overflow causing a left vertical scrollbar to be rendered. clientLeft does not include the left margin or the left padding. clientLeft is read-only.
dom-element-clientleft.title: Element: clientLeft property

dom-element-clienttop.name: clientTop
dom-element-clienttop.summary: The width of the top border of an element in pixels. It is a read-only, integer property of element.
dom-element-clienttop.title: Element: clientTop property

dom-element-clientwidth.name: clientWidth
dom-element-clientwidth.summary: The Element.clientWidth property is zero for inline elements and elements with no CSS; otherwise, it's the inner width of an element in pixels. It includes padding but excludes borders, margins, and vertical scrollbars (if present).
dom-element-clientwidth.title: Element: clientWidth property

dom-element-getboundingclientrect.name: getBoundingClientRect
dom-element-getboundingclientrect.summary: The Element.getBoundingClientRect() method returns a DOMRect object providing information about the size of an element and its position relative to the viewport.

safari_ios.notes: Safari for iOS will modify the effective viewport based on the user zoom. This results in incorrect values whenever the user has zoomed.

dom-element-getboundingclientrect.title: Element: getBoundingClientRect() method

dom-element-getclientrects.name: getClientRects
dom-element-getclientrects.summary: The getClientRects() method of the Element interface returns a collection of DOMRect objects that indicate the bounding rectangles for each CSS border box in a client.
dom-element-getclientrects.title: Element: getClientRects() method

dom-element-scroll.name: scroll
dom-element-scroll.summary: The scroll() method of the Element interface scrolls the element to a particular set of coordinates inside a given element.
dom-element-scroll.title: Element: scroll() method

dom-element-scrollby.name: scrollBy
dom-element-scrollby.summary: The scrollBy() method of the Element interface scrolls an element by the given amount.
dom-element-scrollby.title: Element: scrollBy() method

dom-element-scrollheight.name: scrollHeight
dom-element-scrollheight.summary: The Element.scrollHeight read-only property is a measurement of the height of an element's content, including content not visible on the screen due to overflow.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 21, when an element's content does not generate a vertical scrollbar, then its scrollHeight property is equal to its clientHeight property. This can mean either the content is too short to require a scrollbar or that the element has a CSS style overflow value of visible (non-scrollable).

ie.notes: In Internet Explorer 5 through 7, if padding is set, the value of scrollHeight is equal to the sum of the top and bottom padding. This behavior was fixed in Internet Explorer 8.

dom-element-scrollheight.title: Element: scrollHeight property

dom-element-scrollintoview.name: scrollIntoView
dom-element-scrollintoview.summary: The Element interface's scrollIntoView() method scrolls the element's ancestor containers such that the element on which scrollIntoView() is called is visible to the user.

notes: Only supported for HTMLElement, not all Element objects, such as SVGElement.
No support for smooth behavior or center options.
Before Safari 15.4, there was no support for the smooth behavior.
Before iOS 15.4, there was no support for the smooth behavior.

dom-element-scrollintoview.title: Element: scrollIntoView() method

dom-element-scrollleft.name: scrollLeft
dom-element-scrollleft.summary: The Element.scrollLeft property gets or sets the number of pixels that an element's content is scrolled from its left edge.

chrome.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 0-100 (most left to most right) instead of negative values. See bug 721759.

ie.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 100-0 (most left to most right) instead of negative values.

edge_blink.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 0-100 (most left to most right) instead of negative values. See bug 721759.

dom-element-scrollleft.title: Element: scrollLeft property

dom-element-scrollto.name: scrollTo
dom-element-scrollto.summary: The scrollTo() method of the Element interface scrolls to a particular set of coordinates inside a given element.
dom-element-scrollto.title: Element: scrollTo() method

dom-element-scrolltop.name: scrollTop
dom-element-scrolltop.summary: The Element.scrollTop property gets or sets the number of pixels that an element's content is scrolled vertically.
dom-element-scrolltop.title: Element: scrollTop property

dom-element-scrollwidth.name: scrollWidth
dom-element-scrollwidth.summary: The Element.scrollWidth read-only property is a measurement of the width of an element's content, including content not visible on the screen due to overflow.

ie.notes: In Internet Explorer 5 through 7, if padding is set, the value of scrollWidth is equal to the sum of the left and right padding. This behavior was fixed in Internet Explorer 8.

dom-element-scrollwidth.title: Element: scrollWidth property

extension-to-the-element-interface.name: Element
extension-to-the-element-interface.summary: Element is the most general base class from which all element objects (i.e. objects that represent elements) in a Document inherit. It only has methods and properties common to all kinds of elements. More specific classes inherit from Element.

caniuse.title: Scroll methods on elements (scroll, scrollTo, scrollBy)

extension-to-the-element-interface.title: Element

dom-htmlelement-offsetheight.name: offsetHeight
dom-htmlelement-offsetheight.summary: The HTMLElement.offsetHeight read-only property returns the height of an element, including vertical padding and borders, as an integer.
dom-htmlelement-offsetheight.title: HTMLElement: offsetHeight property

dom-htmlelement-offsetleft.name: offsetLeft
dom-htmlelement-offsetleft.summary: The HTMLElement.offsetLeft read-only property returns the number of pixels that the upper left corner of the current element is offset to the left within the HTMLElement.offsetParent node.
dom-htmlelement-offsetleft.title: HTMLElement: offsetLeft property

dom-htmlelement-offsetparent.name: offsetParent
dom-htmlelement-offsetparent.summary: The HTMLElement.offsetParent read-only property returns a reference to the element which is the closest (nearest in the containment hierarchy) positioned ancestor element.
dom-htmlelement-offsetparent.title: HTMLElement: offsetParent property

dom-htmlelement-offsettop.name: offsetTop
dom-htmlelement-offsettop.summary: The HTMLElement.offsetTop read-only property returns the distance of the outer border of the current element relative to the inner border of the top of the offsetParent, the closest positioned ancestor element.
dom-htmlelement-offsettop.title: HTMLElement: offsetTop property

dom-htmlelement-offsetwidth.name: offsetWidth
dom-htmlelement-offsetwidth.summary: The HTMLElement.offsetWidth read-only property returns the layout width of an element as an integer.
dom-htmlelement-offsetwidth.title: HTMLElement: offsetWidth property

dom-htmlimageelement-x.name: x
dom-htmlimageelement-x.summary: The read-only HTMLImageElement property x indicates the x-coordinate of the element's left border edge relative to the root element's origin.
dom-htmlimageelement-x.title: HTMLImageElement: x property

dom-htmlimageelement-y.name: y
dom-htmlimageelement-y.summary: The read-only HTMLImageElement property y indicates the y-coordinate of the element's top border edge relative to the root element's origin.
dom-htmlimageelement-y.title: HTMLImageElement: y property

dom-mediaquerylist-onchange.name: change_event
dom-mediaquerylist-onchange.summary: The change event of the MediaQueryList interface fires when the status of media query support changes.
dom-mediaquerylist-onchange.title: MediaQueryList: change event

dom-mediaquerylist-matches.name: matches
dom-mediaquerylist-matches.summary: The matches read-only property of the MediaQueryList interface is a boolean value that returns true if the document currently matches the media query list, or false if not.
dom-mediaquerylist-matches.title: MediaQueryList: matches property

dom-mediaquerylist-media.name: media
dom-mediaquerylist-media.summary: The media read-only property of the MediaQueryList interface is a string representing a serialized media query.
dom-mediaquerylist-media.title: MediaQueryList: media property

the-mediaquerylist-interface.name: MediaQueryList
the-mediaquerylist-interface.summary: A MediaQueryList object stores information on a media query applied to a document, with support for both immediate and event-driven matching against the state of the document.
the-mediaquerylist-interface.title: MediaQueryList

the-mediaquerylist-interface.name: MediaQueryListEvent
the-mediaquerylist-interface.summary: The MediaQueryListEvent object stores information on the changes that have happened to a MediaQueryList object  instances are available as the event object on a function referenced by a change event.
the-mediaquerylist-interface.title: MediaQueryListEvent

dom-mediaquerylistevent-mediaquerylistev.name: MediaQueryListEvent
dom-mediaquerylistevent-mediaquerylistev.summary: The MediaQueryListEvent() constructor creates a new MediaQueryListEvent object.
dom-mediaquerylistevent-mediaquerylistev.title: MediaQueryListEvent: MediaQueryListEvent() constructor

dom-mediaquerylistevent-matches.name: matches
dom-mediaquerylistevent-matches.summary: The matches read-only property of the MediaQueryListEvent interface is a boolean value that is true if the document currently matches the media query list, or false if not.
dom-mediaquerylistevent-matches.title: MediaQueryListEvent: matches property

dom-mediaquerylistevent-media.name: media
dom-mediaquerylistevent-media.summary: The media read-only property of the MediaQueryListEvent interface is a string representing a serialized media query.
dom-mediaquerylistevent-media.title: MediaQueryListEvent: media property

dom-mouseevent-offsetx.name: offsetX
dom-mouseevent-offsetx.summary: The offsetX read-only property of the MouseEvent interface provides the offset in the X coordinate of the mouse pointer between that event and the padding edge of the target node.
dom-mouseevent-offsetx.title: MouseEvent: offsetX property

dom-mouseevent-offsety.name: offsetY
dom-mouseevent-offsety.summary: The offsetY read-only property of the MouseEvent interface provides the offset in the Y coordinate of the mouse pointer between that event and the padding edge of the target node.
dom-mouseevent-offsety.title: MouseEvent: offsetY property

dom-mouseevent-pagex.name: pageX
dom-mouseevent-pagex.summary: The pageX read-only property of the MouseEvent interface returns the X (horizontal) coordinate (in pixels) at which the mouse was clicked, relative to the left edge of the entire document. This includes any portion of the document not currently visible.
dom-mouseevent-pagex.title: MouseEvent: pageX property

dom-mouseevent-pagey.name: pageY
dom-mouseevent-pagey.summary: The pageY read-only property of the MouseEvent interface returns the Y (vertical) coordinate in pixels of the event relative to the whole document. This property takes into account any vertical scrolling of the page.
dom-mouseevent-pagey.title: MouseEvent: pageY property

dom-mouseevent-x.name: x
dom-mouseevent-x.summary: The MouseEvent.x property is an alias for the MouseEvent.clientX property.
dom-mouseevent-x.title: MouseEvent: x property

dom-mouseevent-y.name: y
dom-mouseevent-y.summary: The MouseEvent.y property is an alias for the MouseEvent.clientY property.
dom-mouseevent-y.title: MouseEvent: y property

extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.name: MouseEvent
extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.summary: The MouseEvent interface represents events that occur due to the user interacting with a pointing device (such as a mouse). Common events using this interface include click, dblclick, mouseup, mousedown.
extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.title: MouseEvent

dom-range-getboundingclientrect.name: getBoundingClientRect
dom-range-getboundingclientrect.summary: The Range.getBoundingClientRect() method returns a DOMRect object that bounds the contents of the range; this is a rectangle enclosing the union of the bounding rectangles for all the elements in the range.
dom-range-getboundingclientrect.title: Range: getBoundingClientRect() method

dom-range-getclientrects.name: getClientRects
dom-range-getclientrects.summary: The Range.getClientRects() method returns a list of DOMRect objects representing the area of the screen occupied by the range. This is created by aggregating the results of calls to Element.getClientRects() for all the elements in the range.
dom-range-getclientrects.title: Range: getClientRects() method

extensions-to-the-range-interface.name: Range
extensions-to-the-range-interface.summary: The Range interface represents a fragment of a document that can contain nodes and parts of text nodes.

firefox.notes: Starting with Firefox 13, the Range object throws a DOMException as defined in DOM 4, instead of a RangeException defined in prior specifications.

extensions-to-the-range-interface.title: Range

dom-screen-availheight.name: availHeight
dom-screen-availheight.summary: The read-only Screen interface's availHeight property returns the height, in CSS pixels, of the space available for Web content on the screen. Since Screen is exposed on the Window interface's window.screen property, you access availHeight using window.screen.availHeight.
dom-screen-availheight.title: Screen: availHeight property

dom-screen-availwidth.name: availWidth
dom-screen-availwidth.summary: The Screen.availWidth property returns the amount of horizontal space (in pixels) available to the window.
dom-screen-availwidth.title: Screen: availWidth property

dom-screen-colordepth.name: colorDepth
dom-screen-colordepth.summary: The Screen.colorDepth read-only property returns the color depth of the screen. Per the CSSOM, some implementations return 24 for compatibility reasons. See the browser compatibility section for those that don't.

chrome.notes: Starting with version 59 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Starting with Samsung Internet 7.0 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

edge_blink.notes: Starting with version 59 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

dom-screen-colordepth.title: Screen: colorDepth property

dom-screen-height.name: height
dom-screen-height.summary: The Screen.height read-only property returns the height of the screen in pixels.
dom-screen-height.title: Screen: height property

dom-screen-pixeldepth.name: pixelDepth
dom-screen-pixeldepth.summary: Returns the bit depth of the screen. Per the CSSOM, some implementations return 24 for compatibility reasons. See the browser compatibility section for those that don't.

chrome.notes: Starting with version 59 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Starting with Samsung Internet 7.0 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

edge_blink.notes: Starting with version 59 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

dom-screen-pixeldepth.title: Screen: pixelDepth property

dom-screen-width.name: width
dom-screen-width.summary: The Screen.width read-only property returns the width of the screen in CSS pixels.
dom-screen-width.title: Screen: width property

the-screen-interface.name: Screen
the-screen-interface.summary: The Screen interface represents a screen, usually the one on which the current window is being rendered, and is obtained using window.screen.
the-screen-interface.title: Screen

dom-visualviewport-height.name: height
dom-visualviewport-height.summary: The height read-only property of the VisualViewport interface returns the height of the visual viewport, in CSS pixels.
dom-visualviewport-height.title: VisualViewport: height property

dom-visualviewport-offsetleft.name: offsetLeft
dom-visualviewport-offsetleft.summary: The offsetLeft read-only property of the VisualViewport interface returns the offset of the left edge of the visual viewport from the left edge of the layout viewport in CSS pixels.
dom-visualviewport-offsetleft.title: VisualViewport: offsetLeft property

dom-visualviewport-offsettop.name: offsetTop
dom-visualviewport-offsettop.summary: The offsetTop read-only property of the VisualViewport interface returns the offset of the top edge of the visual viewport from the top edge of the layout viewport in CSS pixels.
dom-visualviewport-offsettop.title: VisualViewport: offsetTop property

dom-visualviewport-pageleft.name: pageLeft
dom-visualviewport-pageleft.summary: The pageLeft read-only property of the VisualViewport interface returns the x coordinate of the left edge of the visual viewport relative to the initial containing block origin, in CSS pixels.
dom-visualviewport-pageleft.title: VisualViewport: pageLeft property

dom-visualviewport-pagetop.name: pageTop
dom-visualviewport-pagetop.summary: The pageTop read-only property of the VisualViewport interface returns the y coordinate of the top edge of the visual viewport relative to the initial containing block origin, in CSS pixels.
dom-visualviewport-pagetop.title: VisualViewport: pageTop property

eventdef-window-resize.name: resize_event
eventdef-window-resize.summary: The resize event of the VisualViewport interface is fired when the visual viewport is resized.

chrome.notes: The onresize event handler property is not supported.

edge_blink.notes: The onresize event handler property is not supported.

eventdef-window-resize.title: VisualViewport: resize event

dom-visualviewport-scale.name: scale
dom-visualviewport-scale.summary: The scale read-only property of the VisualViewport interface returns the pinch-zoom scaling factor applied to the visual viewport.
dom-visualviewport-scale.title: VisualViewport: scale property

dom-visualviewport-width.name: width
dom-visualviewport-width.summary: The width read-only property of the VisualViewport interface returns the width of the visual viewport, in CSS pixels.
dom-visualviewport-width.title: VisualViewport: width property

the-visualviewport-interface.name: VisualViewport
the-visualviewport-interface.summary: The VisualViewport interface of the Visual Viewport API represents the visual viewport for a given window. For a page containing iframes, each iframe, as well as the containing page, will have a unique window object. Each window on a page will have a unique VisualViewport representing the properties associated with that window.
the-visualviewport-interface.title: VisualViewport

dom-window-devicepixelratio.name: devicePixelRatio
dom-window-devicepixelratio.summary: The devicePixelRatio of Window interface returns the ratio of the resolution in physical pixels to the resolution in CSS pixels for the current display device.
dom-window-devicepixelratio.title: Window: devicePixelRatio property

dom-window-innerheight.name: innerHeight
dom-window-innerheight.summary: The read-only innerHeight property of the Window interface returns the interior height of the window in pixels, including the height of the horizontal scroll bar, if present.

firefox.notes: From version 4 to 24, this property could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances (see bug 641188).

firefox_android.notes: Before version 24, this property could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances (see bug 641188).

safari_ios.notes: This property returns the height of the visual viewport instead of the layout viewport. See this bug for details.

dom-window-innerheight.title: Window: innerHeight property

dom-window-innerwidth.name: innerWidth
dom-window-innerwidth.summary: The read-only Window property innerWidth returns the interior width of the window in pixels. This includes the width of the vertical scroll bar, if one is present.

firefox.notes: From version 4 to 24, this property could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances (see bug 641188).

firefox_android.notes: Before version 24, this property could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances (see bug 641188).

safari_ios.notes: This property returns the width of the visual viewport instead of the layout viewport. See this bug for details.

dom-window-innerwidth.title: Window: innerWidth property

dom-window-matchmedia.name: matchMedia
dom-window-matchmedia.summary: The Window interface's matchMedia() method returns a new MediaQueryList object that can then be used to determine if the document matches the media query string, as well as to monitor the document to detect when it matches (or stops matching) that media query.
dom-window-matchmedia.title: Window: matchMedia() method

dom-window-moveby.name: moveBy
dom-window-moveby.summary: The moveBy() method of the Window interface moves the current window by a specified amount.
dom-window-moveby.title: Window: moveBy() method

dom-window-moveto.name: moveTo
dom-window-moveto.summary: The moveTo() method of the Window interface moves the current window to the specified coordinates.
dom-window-moveto.title: Window: moveTo() method

the-features-argument-to-the-open()-meth.name: open
the-features-argument-to-the-open()-meth.summary: The open() method of the Window interface loads a specified resource into a new or existing browsing context (that is, a tab, a window, or an iframe) under a specified name.
the-features-argument-to-the-open()-meth.title: Window: open() method

dom-window-outerheight.name: outerHeight
dom-window-outerheight.summary: The Window.outerHeight read-only property returns the height in pixels of the whole browser window, including any sidebar, window chrome, and window-resizing borders/handles.
dom-window-outerheight.title: Window: outerHeight property

dom-window-outerwidth.name: outerWidth
dom-window-outerwidth.summary: Window.outerWidth read-only property returns the width of the outside of the browser window. It represents the width of the whole browser window including sidebar (if expanded), window chrome and window resizing borders/handles.
dom-window-outerwidth.title: Window: outerWidth property

dom-window-pagexoffset.name: pageXOffset
dom-window-pagexoffset.summary: The read-only Window property pageXOffset is an alias for scrollX.
dom-window-pagexoffset.title: Window: pageXOffset property

dom-window-pageyoffset.name: pageYOffset
dom-window-pageyoffset.summary: The read-only Window property pageYOffset is an alias for scrollY; as such, it returns the number of pixels the document is currently scrolled along the vertical axis (that is, up or down) with a value of 0.0, indicating that the top edge of the Document is currently aligned with the top edge of the window's content area.
dom-window-pageyoffset.title: Window: pageYOffset property

resizing-viewports.name: resize_event
resizing-viewports.summary: The resize event fires when the document view (window) has been resized.

chrome.notes: Chrome does not fire a resize event on page load.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 68, Firefox fired a resize event on page load. This is no longer the case.

opera.notes: Opera does not fire a resize event on page load.

opera_android.notes: Opera does not fire a resize event on page load.

webview_android.notes: WebView does not fire a resize event on page load.

edge_blink.notes: Chrome does not fire a resize event on page load.

resizing-viewports.title: Window: resize event

dom-window-resizeby.name: resizeBy
dom-window-resizeby.summary: The Window.resizeBy() method resizes the current window by a specified amount.

firefox.notes: Since Firefox 7, it's no longer possible for a web site to change the default size of a window in a browser if the window wasn't created by window.open or contains more than one tab. See here for more details.

dom-window-resizeby.title: Window: resizeBy() method

dom-window-resizeto.name: resizeTo
dom-window-resizeto.summary: The Window.resizeTo() method dynamically resizes the window.

firefox.notes: Since Firefox 7, it's no longer possible for a web site to change the default size of a window in a browser if the window wasn't created by window.open or contains more than one tab. See here for more details.

dom-window-resizeto.title: Window: resizeTo() method

dom-window-screen.name: screen
dom-window-screen.summary: The Window property screen returns a reference to the screen object associated with the window. The screen object, implementing the Screen interface, is a special object for inspecting properties of the screen on which the current window is being rendered.
dom-window-screen.title: Window: screen property

dom-window-screenleft.name: screenLeft
dom-window-screenleft.summary: The Window.screenLeft read-only property returns the horizontal distance, in CSS pixels, from the left border of the user's browser viewport to the left side of the screen.
dom-window-screenleft.title: Window: screenLeft property

dom-window-screentop.name: screenTop
dom-window-screentop.summary: The Window.screenTop read-only property returns the vertical distance, in CSS pixels, from the top border of the user's browser viewport to the top side of the screen.
dom-window-screentop.title: Window: screenTop property

dom-window-screenx.name: screenX
dom-window-screenx.summary: The Window.screenX read-only property returns the horizontal distance, in CSS pixels, of the left border of the user's browser viewport to the left side of the screen.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 28, Gecko was using device pixels instead of CSS pixels; in other words, it was assuming a value of screenPixelsPerCSSPixel of 1 for any device.

dom-window-screenx.title: Window: screenX property

dom-window-screeny.name: screenY
dom-window-screeny.summary: The Window.screenY read-only property returns the vertical distance, in CSS pixels, of the top border of the user's browser viewport to the top edge of the screen.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 28, Gecko was using device pixels instead of CSS pixels; in other words, it was assuming a value of screenPixelsPerCSSPixel of 1 for any device.

dom-window-screeny.title: Window: screenY property

dom-window-scroll.name: scroll
dom-window-scroll.summary: The Window.scroll() method scrolls the window to a particular place in the document.
dom-window-scroll.title: Window: scroll() method

dom-window-scrollby.name: scrollBy
dom-window-scrollby.summary: The Window.scrollBy() method scrolls the document in the window by the given amount.
dom-window-scrollby.title: Window: scrollBy() method

dom-window-scrollto.name: scrollTo
dom-window-scrollto.summary: Window.scrollTo() scrolls to a particular set of coordinates in the document.
dom-window-scrollto.title: Window: scrollTo() method

dom-window-scrollx.name: scrollX
dom-window-scrollx.summary: The read-only scrollX property of the Window interface returns the number of pixels that the document is currently scrolled horizontally. This value is subpixel precise in modern browsers, meaning that it isn't necessarily a whole number. You can get the number of pixels the document is scrolled vertically from the scrollY property.
dom-window-scrollx.title: Window: scrollX property

dom-window-scrolly.name: scrollY
dom-window-scrolly.summary: The read-only scrollY property of the Window interface returns the number of pixels that the document is currently scrolled vertically.
dom-window-scrolly.title: Window: scrollY property

dom-window-visualviewport.name: visualViewport
dom-window-visualviewport.summary: The visualViewport read-only property of the Window interface returns a VisualViewport object representing the visual viewport for a given window.
dom-window-visualviewport.title: Window: visualViewport property
